results.title: The Job
results.creator_credit: Michael Carson, ABC-TV (Australia) and Michael Jenkins
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Scales of Justice Series”.
The Job is a story of naivety. Probationary Constable Leonard Webber has the makings of a good policeman, but his ideals bring him into conflict with his colleagues. His lack of experience makes him vulnerable and his training has not prepared him for the system, how it works and the rationalisation of the double dealings. Rated: M

results.title: The Numbers
results.creator_credit: Michael Jenkins, ABC-TV (Australia) and Michael Carson
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Scales of Justice Series”.
The Numbers is a story of ambitious and cunning manipulation. Glen Ferris is an astute young politician. At 41 he is already Attorney General, but his revolutionary reforms have weakened his standing in the Senior Cabinet. He needs the numbers, so he decides to use his controversial bill to take on vice-king Artie Roach, a move which makes him a crusader in the public eye while causing discussion in his own parliamentary wing. Rated: M

results.title: The Game
results.creator_credit: Michael Jenkins, ABC-TV (Australia) and Michael Carson
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Scales of Justice Series”.
The Game is a story of jealousy and conflict, personal and professional. Detective Sergeant Draffin and Miles are both from the same mould. Both are ruthlessly ambitious, both boast a reputation of being first class operators, and both are very confident of their ability. However, neither is used to sharing the limelight, and when Draffin is transferred to the Drug Squad, Miles’ home territory, the scene is set for a major confrontation. Rated: M

results.title: Barcelona Chair
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Design Classic Series”.
The Barcelona Chair was designed by the great German architect and designer Mies van de Rohe for the German pavilion at the Great Barcelona Exhibition of 1929. Using chrome and leather, he refined the design to the simplest elements of pure form, creating a cult object for those who can afford it.

results.title: The Aga Cooker
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Design Classic Series”.
Created by a blind Swedish designer Dalen in the 1920s, the Aga Cooker has been a symbol of English country life for the last 60 years. Sir Roy Strong, Director of the Victoria and Albert Museum, enthuses about the virtues of the Aga, as does advertising mogul, David Ogilvy, who began his career by selling the “Rolls Royce” of the kitchen, which cooks like a dream and costs like hell!

results.title: Coke Bottle
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Design Classic Series”.
Drink a bottle of Coke and you participate in the American dream. The words of Stephen Bayly, Director of the Conran Foundation epitomise the global system of Western Capitalism. Alex Samuelson’s bottle design won a competition held by the Coca Cola company in 1915.

results.title: London Underground Map
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Design Classic Series”.
Designed by Harry Beck in 1933, this diagrammatic map hangs on the walls of London’s 273 Underground train stations and in the Metropolitan Museum of Modern Art in New York. A masterpiece of graphic design, it has become a symbol of London all over the world.

results.title: Volkswagen Beetle
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Design Classic Series”.
This car fulfilled Hitler’s dream that ‘everyone should be able to afford a car that would cost the same as a middle-class motorcycle’.

results.title: Civilisation
results.creator_credit: Peter Montagnon, Michael Gill and BBC
results.brief_description: In this groundbreaking television series of thirteen programs, Sir Kenneth Clark presented his personal evaluation of the history and civilisation of Europe from the Dark Ages to the dawning of the 20th century.
